Copyright © 2013 Mythicsoft Ltd. All rights reserved.
FileLocator Pro is the feature extended version of the hugely popular freeware searching utility Agent Ransack.
FileLocator Pro must be registered after the trial period has expired. Registration codes may be obtained via the web site shown below.
For a registration code please visit the web site at:
Privacy policy: Personal information will NOT be sold or distributed
This copy of FileLocator Pro is registered to:

Not quite sure if your regular expression is correct? This window allows you to test the regular expression engine. Simply enter the expression you wish to test along with some sample text and then press Test.
Note: The expression tester uses Perl style regular expressions.
What is the name of the file you want to find?
You don't know the exact name? Not to worry, you can search on parts of the name. If you don't know any part of the name leave it blank.
Would find all documents having My and then Doc somewhere else in the name

Make sure the file name is set to Regular expression in the options tab before using regular expressions, like those shown in the examples. For more complex search "expressions" use the expression wizards available with the Expert User interface.
Would find all documents with MyDoc somwhere in the name
Would find all documents beginning with MyDoc
&Start the search automatically when you click the Finish button
Where do you want to search for the file?
Do you want to search the folder's sub folders as well?
Performance tip: Choosing a specific folder greatly reduces the number of files to be searched and so is usually much faster.
Do you want to search for the file based upon text within the file?
&Yes, search the contents of the file
What text should the file contain?
Would find any file that had a line with the phrase Dear Bill in it.
(e.g. My Dear Bill..., Dear Billy how are you... etc.)
Would find any file that had a line with both the words Dear and Bill in it (e.g. Dear Fred how is Bill..., The dearest items should be rebilled...)
Performance tip: Searching the contents of files can take a long time, especially if a name has not been entered or is not very specific. Therefore, choosing No is usually much faster.
Note: The first name, last name, and email address must be entered exactly as shown in the registration email.
If you have any problems please contact support@mythicsoft.com for assistance.
Note: Drag && Drop to rearrange items
Welcome to the Expression Wizard. This wizard will help you define exactly what you are looking for.
FileLocator Pro uses the concept of 'regular expressions' to describe the patterns for string matching. While regular expressions are very powerful they also tend to be daunting for the uninitiated.

Expression Wizard's purpose is therefore to reduce the complexity of regular expressions without sacrificing the power. Expression Wizard will help build the expression for you by asking you to describe what you are looking in terms easier to understand.
The search specific note goes here.
&Yes. Please insert appropriate backslashes because none of the characters I entered should be treated as special characters.
&No. I am deliberately using special characters for advanced searching.
One or more of the expressions you entered contains at least one of the following special characters: ^$*?+.[]()|\

Special characters are used in regular expressions to define the pattern matching rules and therefore should be used with caution. If you want to search for a character that is also a special character that you must put a backslash before the character.
Would you like Expression Wizard to automatically insert the backslashes before all special characters?
Directory(s) to search (i.e. the Look In field), use -dw for current working directory
Text to search for in specified files
Match case when comparing file names
File name expr type: -fed=DOS, -fex=Regular Expression, -feb=Boolean, -fee=Plain text
Always use command line parameters when creating new or opening existing searches
Override values from file when loading from file AND specifying command line parameters
To switch an option off append 'n' to the flag, e.g.
FileLocatorPro.exe -fmn Switches OFF match case when comparing files
File name shows the file names to exclude
Output filename (runs the search without showing the FileLocator Pro GUI)
Modified before date value, pass "now" as the date to use the current date and time
Modified after date value, pass "now" as the date to use the current date and time
Look In expr type: -leb=Boolean, -lex=Regular Expression, -lee=Plain text
Contents expression spans file (only valid with Boolean expressions)
Overwrite configuration with configuration stored in saved search criteria file
Maximum number of found lines per file to output
DOS Expressions use the standard Windows syntax for specifying a group of files. A semi-colon is used to separate multiple expressions.
*.txt\t\tspecifies all files with a .txt extension\n\n*.xls;*.doc\tspecifies all files with either a .xls or a .doc extension

*.png;*.jpg:holiday		specifies all .png and .jpg files with the word holiday in their name

NOT:*.doc;*.xls			specifies all files except .doc and .xls files

holiday;NOT:*.exe;*.dll		specifies all files except .exe or .dll files with the word holiday in their name
Boolean expressions use the web style search operators AND, OR, NOT, LIKE and NEAR. Boolean searches can be either by line or by file:
work AND document\tsearches for the words 'work' and 'document' in the same line/file
work document\t\tperforms the same search as above (the AND is implicit)
work OR document\tsearches for the words 'work' OR 'document' in the same line/file
work NEAR document\tsearches for 'work' close to the word 'document' in a line/file
"work document"\tsearches for the exact phrase 'work document'
expression is separately tested against each individual line
expression is tested across the whole file
Note: Use parentheses to group expressions, e.g. (work AND doc) OR (special AND case)
Plain Text treats the search criteria text entered as a literal value, i.e. exactly as the text is entered in the edit field. The search criteria matches against all or part of a word.
the author\twould find phrases like 'the author' or 'the authors'.
File Hashing generates a fixed length unique identifier for each file based on the contents of the file. Files with identical contents will produce identical hash values.
1. Specify the hash algorithms from the Options tab
2. Enter the hash value to search for as either a comma separated list of hash values or a pointer to a list of hash values, e.g.
Boolean RegEx expressions are a hybrid of Boolean and Regular Expressions. Regular expressions can be combined using the familiar boolean operators AND, OR, and NOT.
Note: Use parentheses to group expressions, e.g. (work AND doc) OR (special AND case)

Whole Word treats the search criteria text entered as a literal value, i.e. exactly as the text is entered in the edit field, but also matches the beginning and end of the criteria text against the 'word boundary'.
the author\tsearches for the specific phrase 'the author'.

This pane displays any files selected in the File List view. If you are searching by Contents then this pane also displays lines found within the selected files. For available options use the right mouse button to bring up the context menu.
%s is not a valid search directory. The directory name must be a valid path, including the drive letter (e.g. C:\Windows) OR a properly constructed UNC name (e.g. \\WORKSTATION\Shared_Folder).

You must set the Contents to 'Regular Expression' in the Options tab before you can specify the Containing text as a regular expression.

Expression wizard does not provide all the functionality of regular expressions but if you know how to construct regular expressions you can specify any regular expression yourself. Just add your regular expression as type 'Phrase' in the 'Followed by' list and switch off escapes on the next wizard page (which is enabled once you start entering special characters).

Insufficient memory to start new search. Please close previous searches and/or other applications and try again.

Because regular expressions work slightly differently than DOS expressions the result of the Expression Wizard may look different to what you are used to. e.g. The DOS expression 'filename.*' as a regular expression is '^filename\.*'.

FileLocator Pro searches on a line by line basis through the file looking for all lines that match the defined expression. The expression allows you to define how the line should begin, followed by what it should contain, and then how it should end. FileLocator Pro will then finds all lines in the files that match the expression.
